into the centre of the country. ⎡As there was no hope ⎡/
of the Boers allowing the peaceable instruction of the
natives at Kolobeng, I at once resolved to save my
family from exposure to this unhealthy region by
sending them to England, and to return alone, with a
view to exploring the country in search of a healthy
district, that might prove a centre of civilization, and
open up the interior by a path to either the east or west
coast. This resolution led me down to ^ the/ Cape Town in
April, 1852, being the first time during eleven years
that I had revisited the scenes of civilization.

Our route to Cape Town led us to pass
through the centre of the Colony during
the Twentieth month of a
Caffre War, and if those who
periodically pay enormous
sums for these inglorious
affairs, wish to know how
our little unprotected party
could quietly travel through
the heart of the colony to the
Capital with as little sense
or sign of danger as if we
had been in England
they must engage a "Times
Special
Correspondent" Commissioner" for the next
outbreak to explain where
the money goes, and who
hasve been benefitted by the
p blood and treasure they
expended/ are called upon to spend
⎡Having placed my family on
board a homeward bound
ship and promised to rejoin
them it in two years, we parted
for, ^ as it subsequently proved, nearly five years four and a half - The
Directors of the London
Missionary Society signified
their cordial approval of
my project, by leaving the
matter entirely to my own
judgment and discretion; and
I have much pleasure in
p.93 68* 2
acknowledging my obligations
to the gentlemen then in the
composing
that body direction of the Society infor always
acting in an enlightened spirit
and with as much liberality
as their constitution would
allow

I have the like pleasure
in confessing my thankfulness
to the Astronomer Royal
at the Cape, Thomas Maclear
Esqr-Esquire, for enabling me
to recalrecall the little astronomical
knowledge which constant
manual labour and
the engrossing nature of
missionary duties had effaced
from my memory, and in
adding much that I neverdid not
kneow before - before - The assurance
The promise he made on
parting that he would examine
and correct all my observations
had more effect in making
me persevere in overcoming
the difficulties of an unassisted
solitary observer, than anything
else - so whatever credit
may be attached to the
geographical positions laid
down ^ in my route, must
be attributed to the laborious
voluntary aid of the excellent
and laborious astronomer
of the Cape Observatory -

XXXVI- P358-373 3
Dew. W pay, and now began to
Set up in
slips - but in
the type of the
Book JM remark that they
must in future fleece
the Mambari as these
Chiboque had done to us;
As they had all been
loud in condemnation
of the mean^ness & &and when
I asked if they could
descend to be equally
mean,- I was answered
that they would only
do it in revenge - They like
to have a plausible excuse for mean^ness -

Next morning our
guides went only about
a mile, and then told
us they would return
home now - I expected
this befwhen paying them
beforehand in accordance with the
entreaties of the Makololo-, who
are rather ignorant of the world
Very energetic remonstrances
were addressed to the guides of
but they slipped off one by
one in the thick forest
through which we were
passing, and I was glad to
hear my companions
coming to the conclusion,
that, as we were now in
parts visited by traders, we
did not require the guides;
4
whose chief use had been to prevent
misapprehension of our objects
in the minds of the villagers -
The country was somewhat
more undulating now than it
had been, and several fine
small streams flowed in deep woody
dells The trees of
which are
very tall and
straight and
the forests
gloomy and
damp -; the
ground in
these solitudes
is quite covered
with yellow &
moss brown
mosses, and
bright coloured
lichens clothe
all the trees - - The soil is extremely
fertile, and generally a black
loam covered with a thick
crop of tall grasses - We passed
several villages too - The
headman of a large one scolded
us well for passing when
he intended to give us food -
but wWhere slave-traders have
been in the habit of coming,
they present food, then
demand three or four times
its value as a custom - We
were now rather glad to get
past villages without intercourse
with the inhabitants

We were travelling W- N- W-West North West,
and all the rivulets we here
crossed had a Northerly course,
and were reported to fall into
the Kasai or Loké, ^ Most of them
had the peculiar
boggy banks
of the country/ As we
were now in the alledged
latitudes of the Coanza, I was
much astonished at the
entire absence of any
knowledge of that river
2 expressed by the among the
natives of this quarter,
5
But I was ^ then ignorant of the fact
that the Coanza rises considerably
to the West of this, and has
a comparatively short course
from its source to the sea -
The famous Dr Lacerda
seems to have laboured under
the same mistake as myself,
for he recommended the
Government of Angola to
establish a chain of forts
along the banks of that
river, with a view to
communication with the
opposite coast - As a chain
of forts inalong its course would
lead Southwards instead
of Eastwards, we may infer
that the geographical data
within reach of that eminent
man, were no better than
those according to which
I had directed my course
to the Coanza where it does
not exist

26th We spent Sunday on
the banks of the Quilo or
Kweelo here, a stream of
about ten yards wide.
It, runs in a deep glen,
3 the sides of which are
about five hundred yards
of slope - and rockey - the
rocks being hardened tufa above
clayslate ^ and sandstone below - with
a capping of ferrugineousferruginous conglomerate
6
The scenery would have been very
pleasing, but fever took away
much of the joy of life, and
severe daily intermittents
rendered me very weak
and glad to recline

As we were now in the
slave-market, it struck me
that the sense of insecurity
felt by the natives might
account for the circumstance
that when questioned those
who have been sold as slaves,
and freed again, profess to like
this new state better than
their primitive one,- They
lived on rich fertile plains,
which seldom inspire that
love of country which the
mountains do - If they had
been mountaineers they would
have pined for home - To
one who has observed the
hard toil of the poor in old
civilized countries, the state
in which the inhabitants
here live is one of glorious
ease - WeThe country is full
of little villages - Food abounds
4 and very little labour is
required for its cultivation,
The soil is so rich that
no manure is required;
but when a garden becomes
7
5 too poor for good crops of maize,
beans, &c, the owner removes
a little ^ farther into
the forest,/ - applies fire ^ round to the trees
roots of the larger trees to kill
them,- cuts down the smaller,
and a new rich garden is
ready for the seed. The gardens
usually present the appearance
of a great number of deatall
dead trees standing without
bark, and maize growing
between them - The old gardens
continue to yield manioc
for years after the
owners have removed
to other spots for the sake
of beans and maize - But while
vegetable foodaliment is
abundant, there
is a want of
salt & animal
food,- so that
numberless traps
are ^ seen set for
mice in all the
forests of
Londa - The
vegetable aliment
leaves great
craving for
flesh, and I
have no doubt
but that when
an ordinary
quantity of
mixed food
is supplied to
freed slaves,
they actually do
feel more com/-
fortable than
they did at home -
Their assertions,
however, mean but
little, for they try
to give an answer to please, and if one shewedshowed them
a nugget of gold, they would generally says that they abounded in their country -

One could see the
variety of character inamong
the owners of gardens
and villages - Some were
the pictures of neatness
We entered other villages
enveloped in a wilderness
of weeds so high that
5 when sitting on ox back
in the middle of the
village we could only
see the tops of the huts -
If we entered at midday
the owners would come lazily
forth andpipe in hmouth hand
or leizurelyleisurely puffing away
with in dreamy indifference
8
In other villages weeds are not
allowed to grow;- cotton, tobacco,
and different plants, used
as relishes, are planted round
the huts;- fowls are kept
in cages, and the gardens
present the pleasant spectacle
of different kinds of grain
and pulse at various
periods of their growth -
I sometimes admired this, &
at sometimes the other & wished
I could have taken the world
easy likefor a time like the other -
Every fvillage swarms with
children, who turn out to
see the white man pass, -
and run along with strange
cries and antics;- some
run up trees to get a good
view,- - They are good climbers
throughout Londa - At friendly
villages they have scampered
alongside our party for
miles at a time - We usually
make a little hedge around
6 our sheds,, cCrowds of women
come to the entrance of this
it with children on their
backs and long pipes
in their mouths, gazing at
us for hours - The men,
rather than disturb them,
crawl through a hole in
the hedge, and it is common
9
to hear a man in running off
say to them "I am going to tell
my Mama to come and see
the white man's oxen"

Powell In continuing our W- N- W-West North West
course we met many parties
of native traders each carrying
some pieces of cloth and salt
with a few beads to barter for
bees wax - they are all
armed with Portuguese guns
and have cartridges with iron
balls. When we meet we
usually stand a few minutes
they present a little salt and
we ^ give a bit
of ox hide
or some
other trifle
and then part with mutual
good wishes - The hide of
the oxen we slaughtered had
been a valuable addition
to our resources for we
found it in so great
repute as girdles all
through Londa that we
cut up every skin into
stripesstrips about two inches
broad and sold them
7 for meal and manioc
as we went along - As
we came nearer Angola
we found them of less
value as the people
there possess cattle themselves

The village on the
Kweelo at which we spent
10
Sunday was that of a civil
lively old man called
Sakandala - who presented
no objection to our progress -
We found we should soon were entering
on the territory of the
Bashinje, (Chinge of the Portuguese)
who are mixed with
Bangala another tribe people named Bangala
which who have been at war
with the Babindele or
Portuguese - Rains and
fever as usual helped to
impede our progress untilluntil
we were put on the
path which leads from
Cassange and Bihe to
Matiamvo - by a head-man
named Kamboela - This
was a well beaten foot-
path and soon after
entering upon it we
met a party of half
cross breed traders from
Bihe who confirmed
the information we
had already got of
8 this path leading
straight through to
Cassange to w through
which they had come
on their way from
Bihe to Cabango - They
kindly presented my
men with some tobacco
11
and marvelled greatly when
they found that I had
never been able to teach
myself to smoke - On parting
with them we came to
a traderstrader's grave - This was
marked by a huge cone
of wood placed in the
form of the roof of a
hut with a pasllisadepalisade
allarround it - At the an
opening on the Western
side an ugly idol was
placed and several
strings of beads and
bits of cloth were
hung around - We learned
that he had been a cross
breed who had died on
his way back from
Matiamvo

As we ^ were now alone
and sure of being on the
way to the abodes of
civilization we went
trtranspose on briskly - We came
oOn the 30th to a sudden
descent from the highland
9 indented by deep narrow
valleys over which
we had lately been
travelling - It is generally
so steep that it can only
be descended at particular
points and even there
12
I was obliged to dismount
though so weak I had to be
led by my companions
to prevent my toppling over
in walking down - It was
annoying to feel myself
so helpless for I never
liked to see a man either
sick or well giving in
effeminately - Below us
lay the valley of the Quango -
If you sit on the spot
where Mary Queen of
Scots viewed the battle
of Langside and look
down on the vale of
Clyde you may see
in miniature the
glorious sight which
a much greater ^ & richer valley
presented to our view
It is ^ about a forest hundred miles broad
covered generally with
dark ^ forest except by where
the broad light green
grass covered meadow
lands on the Quango
which here and there
glances out in the sun
as it wends its way
10to the North – The opposite
side of this great valley
appears like a range
of lofty mountains
and the descent into it
13
about a mile long which
measured perpendicularly
may be abofrom a thousand
to fifteen hun twelve hundred
feet in perpendicular height
Emerging from the
gloomy forest of Londa
this magnificent prospect
made us all feel as
if a weight had been
lifted off our eyelids
A cloud was passing
accross the middle of
the valley from which
rolling thunder pealed while
above all was glorious
sunlight and when we
went down to the part
where we saw it passing
we found that a very
heavy thunder shower had
fallen under the path
of the cloud – and the bottom
of the valley which from
above seemed quite
smooth is we discovered
to be intersected & furrowed
by great numbers of
deep cut streams – Looking
back from below
11 The descent appears as
the edge of a table land
with numerous indented
dells and spurs are jutting
14
out all along giving it a
serrated appearance - Both
top & sides of the sierra
are covered with trees
but large patches of the
more perpendicular parts
are bare and exhibit
the red soil which is
general over the region
we have now entered

This hollow affords a
section of the part of the
country and we find that
the uppermost stratum is
the ferruginiousferruginous conglomerate
The matrix is rust of iron
and in it are embedded water
worn pebbles of sandstone
and quartz - As this is
the rock underlying the
soil of a large part of
Londa its formation
must have preceded the
work of denudation
which hol washed away
the enormous mass
of matter required before
the valley of Cassange
12 could assume its
present form - The
strata under the conglomerate
are all of red clay slate
of different degrees of
hardness the moset
15
indurated being at the bottom -
The red clay slate is named
Keele in Scotland and has
always been considered
as an indication of gold -
but the only thing we dis-
-covered was it cannot
it had given rise to a very
slippery clay soil veryso different
from that which we
had just left that several
Mashauana who always
prided himself on being
an adept at balancing
himself in the canoe on
water and so sure of foot
on land that he could afford
to express contempt for
anyone less gifted, came
down in a very sudden
and undigniffied manner
to the delight of all whom
he had previously scolded
for falling -

Here we met with the
13 Bamboos as thick as a
man's arm - and many
new trees - others which
we had lost sight of
Shinte's since leaving Shinte's
now reappeared - but
nothing struck us more
than the comparative
scragginess of the trees
in this hollow - Those
16
on the high lands we had
left were tall and straight
here they were stunted and
not by any means so
closely planted together - The
only way I could account
for itthsthis was by supposing
as the trees were different
species ^ that the greater altitude suited
the nature of those above
thanbetter than the lower
14 altitude did the other species
below -

Mead Sunday 2d April - We rested beside
a small stream where we
slaughtered the last spare and
our hunger being now very
severe from having
lived on
manioc ^ alone, since
leaving Ionga
Panza's - we/ slaughtered one of
our four remaining oxen The people of
this district
seem to feel
the craving for
animal food
as much as we
did for they
spend much
energy in digging
large white
larvae out of
the damps
soil adjacent
to their streams/
and use them as a relish for their vegetable diet
The Bashinjé refused to
sell any food for the
poor old ornaments
my men had now to offer
We could get neither meal
nor manioc but would
have been comfortable had
not the Bashinje chief
Sansáwé pestered us for the
customary present - The
native traders informed
us that a display of force
was often necessary
before they could pass
this man - so we

17
Sansawe the chifef of a
portion of the Bashinje shaving
sent the usual formal
demand ofor a man an ox
or a tusk and spoke very
contemptuously of the poor
things we offered him
instead - We shewedshowed his
messengers people that we had nothing
else to offer - Everything
was gone except my
instruments which could
be of no use to them whatever
One of them begged some
meat and when it was
refused said to my men
you may as well give it
for we shall take it all
after when we have killed you
tomorrow - The more humbly
we spoke the more insolent
the Bashinje became, till
at last we were all
feeling savage and sulky
In the evening we
were visited by Sansawe
15 him but continued to speak
as civilly as we could
They are fond of argument
and when we den I denied
their right to demand tribute
from a white man who
did not trade in slaves
an old white headed negro
18
put rather a posing question
"You know that God has
placed chiefs amongs us
whom we ought to honour
and support, you say
that you who have a book
which tells you his will
hHow is it that you
who have a book that tells
you about him do not
come forward at once
to pay this chief tribute
like every one else? I
replied by asking "How
could I know that this
was a chief - who had
allowed me to remain
a day & a half near him
without giving me anything
to eat - ?" This which
to the unintiitiated may
seem sophistry iswas to thes
central Africans quite
a rational question for
274 he at once addmitted
that [food ought to have
been sent and added that
16 probably his chief was
only making it ready
for me and that it
would soon come

After being wearied
by talking all day
wito different parties sent
19
by Sansawe we were honoured
by a visit from himself
WHe is quite a young man
and of rather a pleasing
countenance - There cannot
have been much intercourse
between real Portuguese
and these people even here
so close to the Quango for
Sansawe asked me to
shewshow him my hair ason
the ground that though
he had heard of it and
some had even passed
through his country he
had never seen it
straight hair before - This
is quite possible as
most of the slave
traders are not Portuguese
but cross-breeds - ,The
difference between their
wool and our hair
caused him to burst into
a laughs and the contrast
between the exposed
17 and unexposed parts
of my skin seem to
strike him when
exhibited in evidence
of our all being made
of one stock originally
& were all the children
of one Maker seemed
20
to strike him andwith awe,
wonder, I then shewedshowed him
my watch and wished to
win my way into his
confidence by conversation
but when about to
exhibit my pocket compass
he desired me to desist
as he was afraid of my
wonderful things - I told
him if he had known
mey ^ aims as / the tribes in the
Interior had done did and
x as I hoped he would yet
know methem & me he
would have been glad to
stay & to see evenalso the pictures
of the Magic Lantern - but
as it was now getting
dark he had evidently
got enough of my witchery
and began to use some
charms to dispel any
kindly feelings he may
have felt stealing round
his heart - He asked leave
to go and when his
18 party moved off a little
way he sent for my
head spokesman spokesman
and told him that "if
Iwe did not add a red jacket
and a man to our gift
of a few copper rings &
a few pounds of meat"
21
I observed my companions
remark in their own tongue in answer to
threats of attack with clenched
teeth "that's what we want"
"only begin then" - or with
clenched teeth they would
exclaim to each other
"these slaves things have never
travelled and do not know
what men are" - The
worrying of which I give
only a slight sketch had
considerable influence
on my own mind - The
more especially as it
was impossible now
to make any allowance
for the Bashinje such
as we I was willing
to award to the Chiboque
They saw ^ that we had nothing
to give nor would they
be benefitted in the least
by enforcing the impudent
order to return whence
we had come - They were
adding insult to injury
and this put us all
20 into a fighting spirit which
as far as and as nearly
as we could judge we
expected to be obliged to
cut our way through the
Bashinje next morning.
